text:
I am feeling fairly hopeful about the UK's ability to hit 2 million vaccinations/week by end of January.

The 1million in the last month was with about 1 vaccination site for every 6 GP practices.
With the Oxford vaccine because it's so easy to deal with, being it only needs normal fridge and there is no need to observe people for 15minutes after it's going to be much better.
They say they are planning for every GP practice.
Plus pharmacists.
Plus mass vaccination centers (which are due to open 2nd week of January)

According to the defense secretary (so take it with more than a few grains of salt) they have 250 trained teams of military personnel who estimate they can do 100,000 vaccinations per day.

And while I am reading that volunteers are hella frustrated with how hard it is to get certified to be allowed to volunteer, they still have recruited thousands of people.

So while I think it will be a pretty shaky first few weeks, I am hopeful.

text: I'm very worried by the plan of delaying the second dose to 12 weeks and the rumors about using a different vaccine for the second dose, both of them with no testing whatsoever

elements.text: I'm very worried by the plan of delaying the second dose to 12 weeks and the rumors about using a different vaccine for the second dose, both of them with no testing whatsoever

text:
The 2nd dose thing isn't really real.
It's not that they plan on doing it, but it's a contingency allowance basically for of we lose records of what vaccine they had first, or if we lose ability to get one of the vaccines.
It's not going to happen, the same document says to not do it

elements.text:
The 2nd dose thing isn't really real.
It's not that they plan on doing it, but it's a contingency allowance basically for of we lose records of what vaccine they had first, or if we lose ability to get one of the vaccines.
It's not going to happen, the same document says to not do it

text:
The 12 week thing is a bit more iffy.


One big screwup IMO was imposing on people who've already had the first.
Making doctors practices have to reschedule literally thousands of people is a ton of extra work when already so very busy.

And while 12 weeks is outside what was studied properly, it's inside some limit, there was a reason they went with 12 and not 14.
I can't recall what it was.
Maybe what was shown to be safe in earlier studies?


And we do basically have figures showing how effective a single dose is from the part of the study that occurred between the dosing.
And that looked pretty good.
Do getting that out there could have big impact.

I do think it is also bad that they are undermining public confidence.

While I don't think it was the best thing to do, I don't think it's terrible.
